item.title: The Elephant in The Event Loop
item.description: Everybody knows that JavaScript is Single Threaded. You associate one or more handler functions with one or more potential events. Whenever any of those events actualizes the JS runtime records it in a message and puts it on the message queue.

item.description: Event Driven Architecture has a few gotchas. Things that you always need to be aware of or think about to make your system reliable.

item.description: Visual Studio 2022 for Mac keeps trudging along toward general availability several months behind its Windows cousin, with the latest preview introducing new Azure Functions V4 tooling and reintroducing Xamarin mobile tooling.

item.title: ASP.NET Core and Blazor Identity and State
item.description: Over the past several weeks I’ve been wrestling with the way in which ASP.NET Core (aspnetcore) and server-side Blazor manage things like context, identity, and state. This post won’t cover everything, but I want to at least document what I’ve learned (with the help of some great people from the #cslanet community).
item.author: (Rockford Lhotka)

item.title: Roll your own crypto, then smoke it.
item.description: The July 31st, 2021 episode of the Security, Cryptography, Whatever podcast was the great “roll your own crypto”1 debate between Thomas Ptacek and Filippo Valsorda, moderated by Deirdre Connolly, with additional commentary provided by me. Loosely, Filippo was arguing that the mantra of “don’t roll your own crypto” has been ineffective and mostly serves as a form of gatekeeping in which the people the phrase is targeted at don’t listen to it anyway.

item.title: Live Unit Testing Preview: Better and Faster
item.description: Significant improvements across full functionality of Live Unit Testing are available under a preview feature flag including supporting more solutions out-of-the-box than before, better handling of large solutions, better default behavior working with large test sets, better cancellation abilities of test runs in progress, and more configuration options with new Live Unit Testing wizard and Lutignore file.
item.author: (Vritant Bhardwaj)

item.title: Announcing .NET 7 Preview 2 - The New, 'New' Experience
item.description: Today, we are glad to release .NET 7 Preview 2. The second preview of .NET 7 includes enhancements to RegEx source generators, progress moving NativeAOT from experimental status into the runtime, and a major set of improvements to the “dotnet new”
item.author: (Angelos Petropoulos)

item.title: How our free plan stays free
item.description: TL;DR: Tailscale’s free plan is free because we keep our scaling costs low relative to typical SaaS companies. We care about privacy, so unlike some other freemium models, you and your data are not the product. Rather, increased word-of-mouth from free plans sells the more valuable corporate plans. I know, it sounds too good to be true. Let’s see some details.
item.author: (Tailscale)

item.title: ASP.NET Core updates in .NET 7 Preview 2
item.description: .NET 7 Preview 2 is now available and includes many great new improvements to ASP.NET Core. Here’s a summary of what’s new in this preview release: Infer API controller action parameters that come from services Dependency injection for SignalR hub methods Provide endpoint descriptions and summaries for minimal APIs Binding arrays and StringValues from headers and query strings in minimal APIs Customize the cookie consent value For more details on the ASP.NET Core work planned for .NET 7 see the full ASP.NET Core roadmap for .NET 7 on GitHub.
item.author: (Daniel Roth)
